Description: Apple scab is a common fungal disease that affects the leaves, fruit, and young twigs of apple trees. It appears as dark, olive-green spots on the leaves and fruit, which can become black and scabby over time.
Cause: Apple scab is caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis.
Prevention: Use resistant apple varieties, apply fungicides at the recommended times, and practice good sanitation by removing fallen leaves and infected fruit.
Medication: Use fungicides such as captan, myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl.

Description: Black rot is a serious fungal disease affecting apple trees. It causes fruit rot, leaf spots, and limb cankers, leading to significant crop losses.
Cause: Black rot is caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa.
Prevention: Remove infected fruit and twigs, apply fungicides, and prune trees to improve air circulation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as benomyl, thiophanate-methyl, or captan.

Description: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease that requires two hosts: apple and cedar trees. It causes yellow-orange spots on apple leaves and galls on cedar trees.
Cause: Cedar apple rust is caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae.
Prevention: Remove nearby cedar trees, use resistant apple varieties, and apply appropriate fungicides.
Medication: Use fungicides such as myclobutanil, propiconazole, or sulfur.

Description: Healthy apple trees show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green, and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and fertilization.

Healthy blueberry plants show no signs of disease or pest damage.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and fertilization.

Description: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease that affects cherry trees, covering leaves with a white powdery substance.
Cause: Powdery mildew is caused by the fungus Podosphaera clandestina.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, improve air circulation, and apply fungicides as needed.
Medication: Use fungicides such as sulfur, neem oil, or potassium bicarbonate.

Description: Healthy cherry trees show no signs of disease or pest damage.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and fertilization.

Description: Gray leaf spot is a fungal disease that affects corn, causing rectangular lesions on leaves.
Cause: Gray leaf spot is caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, rotate crops, and apply fungicides.
Medication: Use fungicides such as azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, or propiconazole.

Description: Common rust is a fungal disease that affects corn, causing rust-colored pustules on leaves.
Cause: Common rust is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and manage plant density.
Medication: Use fungicides such as mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or tebuconazole.

Description: Northern leaf blight is a fungal disease that affects corn, causing long, elliptical, grayish-green or tan lesions on leaves.
Cause: Northern leaf blight is caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, rotate crops, and apply fungicides.
Medication: Use fungicides such as azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, or propiconazole.

Description: Healthy corn plants show no signs of disease or pest damage.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper fertilization, watering, and pest control.

Description: Black rot is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing dark brown spots on leaves and black, shriveled fruit.
Cause: Black rot is caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii.
Prevention: Remove infected plant material, apply fungicides, and ensure proper vineyard sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as myclobutanil, trifloxystrobin, or captan.

Description: Esca, also known as black measles, is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing dark streaks in the wood and black spotting on leaves.
Cause: Esca is caused by a complex of fungi including Phaeoacremonium aleophilum and Togninia minima.
Prevention: Remove and destroy infected wood, avoid wounding vines, and apply fungicides if necessary.
Medication: Use fungicides such as flutriafol, carbendazim, or pyraclostrobin.

Description: Leaf blight, also known as Isariopsis leaf spot, is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing brown, angular spots on leaves.
Cause: Leaf blight is caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora vitis.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good vineyard sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or copper hydroxide.

Description: Healthy grapevines show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and pest control.

Description: Huanglongbing (HLB), also known as citrus greening, is a bacterial disease that affects citrus trees, causing yellowing of leaves and misshapen fruit.
Cause: HLB is caused by the bacterium Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus and spread by the Asian citrus psyllid.
Prevention: Control psyllid populations, remove infected trees, and use HLB-tolerant rootstocks.
Medication: Use antibiotics such as streptomycin or oxytetracycline under regulatory guidelines.

Description: Bacterial spot is a disease that affects peach trees, causing dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit.
Cause: Bacterial spot is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply bactericides, and practice good orchard sanitation.
Medication: Use bactericides such as copper hydroxide or streptomycin.

Description: Bacterial spot is a disease that affects bell pepper plants, causing dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit.
Cause: Bacterial spot is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply bactericides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use bactericides such as copper hydroxide or streptomycin.

Description: Healthy bell pepper plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper fertilization, watering, and pest control.

Description: Early blight is a fungal disease that affects potato plants, causing dark, concentric spots on leaves and tubers.
Cause: Early blight is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and rotate crops.
Medication: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin.

Description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease that affects potato plants, causing water-soaked lesions on leaves and tubers.
Cause: Late blight is caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or fluazinam.

Description: Healthy potato plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and tubers develop normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper fertilization, watering, and pest control.

Description: Healthy raspberry plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and fertilization.

Description: Healthy soybean plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and pods develop normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper fertilization, watering, and pest control.

Description: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease that affects squash plants, covering leaves with a white powdery substance.
Cause: Powdery mildew is caused by the fungus Podosphaera xanthii.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, improve air circulation, and apply fungicides as needed.
Medication: Use fungicides such as sulfur, neem oil, or potassium bicarbonate.

Description: Leaf scorch is a fungal disease that affects strawberry plants, causing dark brown spots on leaves that can merge and kill the leaf.
Cause: Leaf scorch is caused by the fungus Diplocarpon earlianum.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as captan, myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl.

Description: Healthy strawberry plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper pruning, watering, and fertilization.

Description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease that affects tomato plants, causing dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Cause: Bacterial spot is caused by several species of the bacterium Xanthomonas.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply bactericides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use bactericides such as copper hydroxide or streptomycin.

Description: Early blight is a common fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing dark, concentric rings on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Cause: Early blight is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and rotate crops.
Medication: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin.

Description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing large, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Cause: Late blight is caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or fluazinam.

Description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing yellow spots on the upper leaf surface and a velvety, olive-green mold on the underside.
Cause: Leaf mold is caused by the fungus Passalora fulva.
Prevention: Improve air circulation, reduce humidity, and apply fungicides.
Medication: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper fungicides.

Description: Septoria leaf spot is a fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing small, circular, gray spots with dark borders on leaves.
Cause: Septoria leaf spot is caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper fungicides.

Description: Two-spotted spider mite infestations cause stippling and bronzing on tomato leaves, leading to leaf drop and reduced yields.
Cause: Two-spotted spider mites are caused by the mite Tetranychus urticae.
Prevention: Use miticides, encourage natural predators, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use miticides such as abamectin, bifenazate, or spiromesifen.

Description: Target spot is a fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing concentric rings and dark lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Cause: Target spot is caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides, and practice good field sanitation.
Medication: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin.

Description: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) is a viral disease that affects tomato plants, causing yellowing and curling of leaves and stunted growth.
Cause: TYLCV is transmitted by the whitefly Bemisia tabaci.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, control whitefly populations, and use reflective mulches.
Medication: Use insecticides such as imidacloprid, spinosad, or neem oil.

Description: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) is a viral disease that affects tomato plants, causing mottling, yellowing, and distortion of leaves and fruit.
Cause: ToMV is caused by the tomato mosaic virus.
Prevention: Use resistant varieties, practice good sanitation, and control insect vectors.
Medication: Use insecticides such as imidacloprid, spinosad, or neem oil.

Description: Healthy tomato plants show no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and fruit develops normally.
Prevention: Regular care and maintenance including proper fertilization, watering, and pest control.
